headline.main: De Gustibus; DESPITE DIET CONSCIOUNESS, MENU FAVORITES PERSIST

docs.lead_paragraph: So much is heard about concern with diet and health these days that it is easy to get the impression that American eating habits have undergone radical changes. However, based on a national menu census of 1981 sales of food services taken by the trade magazine Restaurants & Institutions, such concern apparently exists only in the lofty and costly realm of high-fashion dining. Reading about the hazards of salt, saturated fats and obesity, and considering answers that consumers give when asked about their changed eating habits, it is sobering to learn that the best-selling sandwiches in all price categories are hamburgers and cheeseburgers, with ham and cheese and hot dogs next in line. The best-selling sidedish vegetable is French fries; only in restaurants where the average check is above $10 do mushrooms become the preferred side dish.
